title: What is the differential equation solution for (X^2 * y') + 2xy - y^3 =0? - Quora

response.answer_text: [math]x^2 y' + 2xy - y^3 = 0[/math] Start by noticing that [math]y = 0[/math] is a solution. All other solutions don’t cancel. Then we can divide by [math]y^3[/math]. Rewrite the equation as: [math]x^2 \dfrac{y'}{y^3} + 2x\dfrac{1}{y^2} = 1[/math] Substitute [math]u = \frac{1}{y^2}[/math], with [math]u' = -2\frac{y'}{y^3}[/math]: [math]-\dfrac{x^2}{2} u' + 2xu = 1[/math] For [math]x \not= 0[/math], multiply by [math]-\frac{2}{x^2}[/math]: [math]u' - \dfrac{4}{x}u = - dfrac{2}{x^2}[/math] One integrating factor is [math]\frac{1}{x^4}[/math]; multiplying: [math]\dfrac{1}{x^4} u' + \dfrac{-4}{x^5} u = - \dfrac{2}{x^6}[/math] Now the LHS is a derivative: [math]\left( \dfrac{u}{x^4} \right)' = - \dfrac{2}{x^6}[/math] Integrating both sides: [math]\dfrac{u}{x^4} = - \dfrac{2}{5} \dfrac{1}{x^5} + \dfrac{C}{5}, \ C \in \mathbb{R}[/math] Multiplying by [math]x^4[/math]: [math]u(x) = \dfrac{C}{5}x^4 - \dfrac{2}{5} \dfrac{1}{x}[/math] this is, [math]u(x) = \dfrac{Cx^5 - 2}{5x}[/math] We return to [math]y[/math]: [math]\dfrac{1}{y^2(x)} = \dfrac{Cx^5 - 2}{5x}[/math] This is, [math]y^2(x) = \dfrac{5x}{Cx^5 - 2}[/math] Remember that this is for [math]x \not= 0[/math]. Because we want differentiable solutions, they are continuous and so each solution is defined only for one of the following: [math]x > 0[/math] or [math]x < 0[/math]. Notice that [math]x[/math] and [math]Cx^5 - 2[/math] must have the same sign, since [math]y^2 > 0[/math] for all (real and non-trivial) solution [math]y[/math]. In those conditions, two general solutions are: [math]y(x) = - \sqrt{ \dfrac{5x}{Cx^5 - 2} }[/math] [math]y(x) = \sqrt{ \dfrac{5x}{Cx^5 - 2} }[/math] In conclusion, the solutions of the ODE are: [math]y(x) = 0, \ \forall x \in \mathbb{R}[/math] [math]y(x) = - \sqrt{ \dfrac{5x}{C_1x^5 - 2} }, \ \forall x \in \mathbb{R^-}[/math] [math]y(x) = \sqrt{ \dfrac{5x}{C_1x^5 - 2} }, \ \forall x \in \mathbb{R^-}[/math] [math]y(x) = - \sqrt{ \dfrac{5x}{C_2x^5 - 2} }, \ \forall x \in \mathbb{R^+}[/math] [math]y(x) = \sqrt{ \dfrac{5x}{C_2x^5 - 2} }, \ \forall x \in \mathbb{R^+}[/math] where [math]C_1, C_2 \in \mathbb{R}[/math] satisfy [math]C_1x^5 - 2 < 0[/math] and [math]C_2x^5 - 2 > 0[/math]. Note: Given an initial condition, only one of these is the particular solution of the associated Cauchy’s problem; in other words, only one will satisfy the initial condition.
